description: From Middle English scar, scarre, a conflation of Old French escare (“scab”) (from Late Latin eschara, from Ancient Greek ἐσχάρα (eskhára, “scab left from a burn”), and thus a doublet of eschar) and Middle English skar (“incision, cut, fissure”) (from Old Norse skarð (“notch, chink, gap”), from Proto-Germanic *skardaz (“gap, cut, fragment”)). Akin to Old Norse skor (“notch, score”), Old English sċeard (“gap, cut, notch”). More at shard.

entries.meaning: A permanent mark on the skin, sometimes caused by the healing of a wound.
(by extension) A permanent negative effect on someone's mind, caused by a traumatic experience.
Any permanent mark resulting from damage.
examples: Her age-old weapons, flood and fire, left scars on the canyon which time will never efface.

verbs.description: scar (third-person singular simple present scars, present participle scarring, simple past and past participle scarred)

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To affect deeply in a traumatic manner.
examples: Seeing his parents die in a car crash scarred him for life.

description: From Middle English scarre, skarr, skerre, sker, a borrowing from Old Norse sker (“an isolated rock in the sea; skerry”). Cognate with Icelandic sker, Norwegian skjær, Swedish skär, Danish skær, German Schäre. Doublet of skerry.

entries.meaning: A rock in the sea breaking out from the surface of the water.
A bare rocky place on the side of a hill or mountain.

description: From Latin scarus (“a kind of fish”), from Ancient Greek σκάρος (skáros, “parrot wrasse, Sparisoma cretense, syn. Scarus cretensis”).

entries.meaning: A marine food fish, the scarus or parrotfish (family Scaridae).
